programme.title: Can women save sumo? The crossroads facing Japan's national sport
programme.desc: The ancient Japanese sport of sumo is in well-documented crisis. Years of controversy and scandal have hurt the sport's ability to attract new talent. But new energy is brewing in Tokyo's Ryōgoku district, where the sport is slowly adapting to life in the 21st century, and where - despite being banned from the professional ring itself - women are flocking to watch it like never before. Will it be enough to save Japan's national sport in the 21st century?

programme.title: My life in a hotel room: Ireland’s hidden homeless crisis
programme.desc: Nuala and her teenage daughter, Laura, were suddenly evicted from their Dublin home when their landlord of 10 years was forced to sell by his creditors. They haven’t been able to find a new place to rent. Despite having been on the council house waiting list for more than six years they are still only around 600th in line. Now, like almost 10,000 other people and 1,700 families across Ireland, Nuala and Laura are homeless..

programme.title: Death at Sea | Inner-city cricket: The Midlands. Is ethnic minority talent being missed?
programme.desc: Death at sea: Syrian migrants film their perilous voyage to Europe | Inner-city cricket: The Midlands. Is ethnic minority talent being missed?

programme.title: The "Spider-Man" of Sudan: the real-life superhero of the protest movement
programme.desc: In Sudan's capital, Khartoum, an anonymous protester dressed as Spider-Man joins the hundreds of thousands of protesters desperate to protect their fragile civilian government after the military coup in October 2021. 'Spidey' has become well known on social media for leaping from billboards and scaling the tops of buildings while dodging teargas. However, it's his work with some of the poorest children in Khartoum that has shown him to be a positive focus for the resistance, helping a new generation to know their worth and take pride in their country's rich heritage.

programme.title: Killing Gävle
programme.desc: In the small city of Gävle, northern Sweden, there is an annual fight between local custodians and mischievous pagans for the spirit of Christmas. Each year since 1966, business owners have paid for a 13-metre (40ft) effigy of a goat to be made of straw and displayed in the central square from the first day of Advent. In 37 of those years, the goat has been burned down or damaged by shadowy outsiders, sometimes within a few hours of going up.

programme.title: Blood, sweat and fears: special report on abuse towards grassroots football referees
programme.desc: The FA has rebooted its Respect Campaign this season to protect grassroots referees in England but many continue to suffer both mental and physical abuse. There are some horrifying stories but hope remains: as of 2019-20 season a new sin-bin system will be rolled out across all grassroots leagues for anybody caught abusing a referee, with other initiatives also in the pipeline.

programme.title: La caravana: On the road with the migrant caravan
programme.desc: Thousands of migrants from Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala head north hoping to find work and a better life in the US. The largest Central American caravan in decades keeps growing as thousands more join this journey – but when they reach Mexico, the migrant caravan starts taking different directions.

programme.title: Radical Brownies
programme.desc: Berets, badges, Black Lives Matter and social justice: the youth group for activist girls of colour.

programme.title: The Apache war against copper mining: 'this is an act of desecration'
programme.desc: Chí’chil Biłdagoteel - otherwise known as Oak Flat, Arizona – is regarded as sacred ancestral land by the Apache people. With the territory at risk of being sold for copper mining to a subsidiary of Rio Tinto, resident Wendsler Nosie has set up a protest movement from his tipi, alongside his daughter and granddaughter. With no support from the courts, Wendsler and the community are anxiously hoping the Biden administration will pause the land transfer. With religious freedom and environmental protection at risk, they await the call with further news.

programme.title: The new green superpower? Oil giant Kazakhstan tries to wean itself off the black stuff
programme.desc: Kazakhstan is rich with oil, gas and coal but Nursultan Nazarbayev, its president for life, has committed the country to a dramatic shift from fossil fuels to green energy. Is this huge nation, which is beset by rural poverty, major infrastructure challenges and environmental crises, able to realise his vision? Phoebe Greenwood travels to the Kazakh capital, Astana, and the Aral Sea region.

programme.title: Working nights to pack your California strawberries, working days to graduate from school
programme.desc: Ashley Solis is a Mexican American teenager, farmworker and factory worker who dreams of being the first in her family to graduate from high school and go to college. Her mother is undocumented, and like many families with mixed documented status, they face the threat of family separation. With responsibility for earning enough to look after her sisters, Ashley balances working nights in a California strawberry-freezing factory with her school attendance.

programme.title: Dearborn, Michigan
programme.desc: In the last 12 months the city of Dearborn, Michigan, has been thrown into conflict. At its heart, the conflict is about fear, ideology and identity politics – and what it means to be an American. Dearborn, home to the largest mosque in North America, is a place of apparent contradictions: simultaneously a sleepy, affluent suburb and yet also the subject of rumours about Isis terror cells and sharia law.

programme.title: Quipu: Calls for Justice
programme.desc: Esperanza and Teodula are calling for justice in rural Peru, part of 300,000 people sterilised without consent more than 18 years ago. The Quipu Project is their phoneline that allows victims across the country to share their shocking testimonies and ensure those responsible are punished.

programme.title: Fighting Shame
programme.desc: A group of women use everyday items to tell of the sacrifices and difficult choices they face, and the community initiatives they have launched in an attempt to tackle the shame surrounding poverty and make policymakers listen.

programme.title: The internet warriors
programme.desc: Who are the people that get so angry online? Meet the internet warriors, in their own homes.

programme.title: Black Sheep
programme.desc: Black Sheep tells the story of Cornelius Walker, whose life changed on 27 November 2000 - the day Damilola Taylor was killed. Damilola was 10, the same age as Cornelius. He lived five minutes away. He had the same skin colour. Cornelius’s mother, scared for her son’s safety, moved their family out of London. Cornelius suddenly found himself living on a white estate run by racists. But rather than fight them, Cornelius decided to become more like the people who hated him.

programme.title: The 'Lost Rambos' of Papua New Guinea: how weapons and Hollywood changed tribal disputes
programme.desc: Tribal fighting has long been present in the Papua New Guinea highlands but the influx of modern automatic weaponry in the 1990s turned local disputes into lethal exchanges that threatened to permanently reshape highlands culture. Bootleg copies of the US film Rambo circulated in remote communities, becoming a crude tutorial on the use of such weaponry. The film's influence was so pronounced that the term Rambo is used in Papuan dialects to describe hired mercenaries.

programme.title: Space to Be: the fight to keep this Belfast women’s centre open
programme.desc: In the heart of the Village, a loyalist area in Belfast, the Windsor Women’s Centre has fought a 30-year battle to keep its doors open. The centre, an oasis for vulnerable women, is deeply rooted in the community. As it faces financial insecurity and navigates the pandemic, will these women make it through their toughest year so far?

programme.title: Inside Out: Indigenous imprisonment in Australia
programme.desc: Filmed on the plains of north-western New South Wales, this documentary looks at one man's fight against the scourge of Indigenous imprisonment in his community. Inside Out tells the story of a pastor and former prison guard, Uncle Isaac Gordon, whose dream is to see the numbers of Aboriginal youths heading to jail slashed. Gordon wants to build a 'healing centre' for troubled Aboriginal young people at risk of jail time, built on his family's ancestral land near the towns of Brewarrina and Walgett. But will government bodies get on board?

programme.title: The island
programme.desc: Christmas Island, off the coast of Australia: here 50 million crabs make their slow and ancient migration from the jungle to the ocean's edge, while thousands of people seeking asylum are indefinitely held in a high security detention facility. Poh Lin, a trauma counsellor living on the island, bears witness to the dramatic stories and decline of those being detained.

programme.title: Heroin to Holyrood? Man behind 'illegal' drug van runs for Scottish parliament
programme.desc: Peter Krykant, who operates a van in Glasgow where people can safely take illegal drugs, is running for Holyrood as part of a campaign calling for the Scottish government to establish legal sites. A former heroin addict, he is pushing for drug reform in Scotland, which has a reported drug deaths rate 15 times higher than the European average. "People are dying out there,' says Krykant, who is able to treat addicts who overdose in his van. Could interventions such as his change Scotland's status as Europe's drug deaths capital?

programme.title: Saintmaking: the canonisation of Derek Jarman by queer 'nuns'
programme.desc: This year marks the 30th anniversary of film-maker Derek Jarman’s canonisation by an activist group of gay male 'nuns' known as the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence. At the time in 1991, Derek Jarman was the most prominent person in the UK living openly with HIV. He was outspoken, radical and unapologetically queer. The perfect antidote, in the Sisters’ eyes, to Ian McKellen’s acceptance of a knighthood in the 1991 new year honours.

programme.title: The County - what happens after police kill someone you love?
programme.desc: When someone dies after an encounter with law enforcement, he leaves behind parents and children, loss and confusion. What’s to be done when those people sworn to protect you are the same people who pull the trigger?

programme.title: Finding Ashley | Murder, corruption and cattle barons in Kenya
programme.desc: Finding Ashley: a Native American family's desperate search for their missing relative | Murder, corruption and cattle barons in Kenya

programme.title: Nowt but a fleeting thing
programme.desc: A film about a young farmer’s connection to the land, his animals and a changing world in the north of England. Battling against unsustainable farming methods and an unenthusiastic market, Adam Crowe continues to work on two neighbouring farms while fighting to launch his own business and breed a flock of sheep. In rural Britain, the threat of poverty is often frighteningly close

programme.title: Fish story
programme.desc: Sometime in the 1980s, Caspar Salmon's grandmother was invited to a gathering on the Welsh island of Anglesey, attended exclusively by people with fish surnames. Or so he says. Thirty years later, film-maker Charlie Lyne attempts to sort myth from reality.

programme.title: Four weddings
programme.desc: Not all weddings are about marrying a prince. This documentary tells the story of four special weddings around the world from the point of view of the bride. Featuring a British woman unsure of the future, a soldier discharged from Iraq, a high society Indian wedding and a rural Romanian celebration, this is what really happens behind the scenes on the wedding day

programme.title: World Cup Slaves
programme.desc: Nepalese men employed in Qatar's construction industry tell Robert Booth how they work for little or no pay as they build the infrastructure ahead of the 2022 football World Cup. Appalling living conditions and unsafe employment are not the only difficulties they face: there is pressure and disbelief from families in Nepal when no money is sent back home

programme.title: Italian mafia’s cocaine trafficking leaves trail of drug devastation among poor of Brazil
programme.desc: The all-powerful Calabrian crime syndicate 'Ndrangheta has forged a deadly network of drug trafficking routes through Brazil – 80% of all cocaine arriving in Europe comes through the country's Santos port. To mark International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking, we hear from the anti-'Ndrangheta experts risking their lives to speak out against the syndicate, and take to the streets of Brazil's Crackolândia districts, where crack addiction is destroying lives.

programme.title: How to fix space's junk problem | Too black for Brazil
programme.desc: No TV, no sat nav, no internet: how to fix space's junk problem | Too black for Brazil

programme.title: Cops and Robbers
programme.desc: Growing up in the Jamaica district of Queens in the 70s and 80s, Corey Pegues played cops and robbers like all the other kids on the block but he never expected to become both.

programme.title: Home match
programme.desc: One crucial year in the life of Alina Shilova, a young Ukrainian woman born and raised in the poor suburbs of Kiev, who is torn between playing football and looking after her family.

programme.title: The Circle: masculinity, racism and brotherhood on a Hackney estate
programme.desc: Two brothers living on a council estate in Hackney, east London, express their experiences of masculinity, racism and brotherhood through dance and direct testimony. Revealing interviews are set against dynamic movement sequences, communicating their histories and emotions in a way that words alone could not. This imaginative film explores experiences of anxiety and depression while uncovering love and vulnerability in a close-knit community

programme.title: Behind the scenes of Seahorse documentary | If I die on Mars
programme.desc: If all men got pregnant, it'd be taken more seriously': behind the scenes of Seahorse | If I die on Mars: meet the people on a mission to be first on the red planet ... and stay there

programme.title: The complex racial identity of a tiny Ohio town| Organising a rural UK Black Lives Matter protest
programme.desc: You don't have to look black to be black: The complex racial identity of a tiny Ohio town | I'm very aware I’m mixed race here: organising a rural UK Black Lives Matter protest

programme.title: Beyond bionics: how the future of prosthetics is redefining humanity
programme.desc: Bionic technology is removing physical barriers faced by disabled people while raising profound questions of what it is to be human. From DIY prosthetics realised through 3D printing technology to customised AI-driven limbs, science is at the forefront of many life-enhancing innovations

programme.title: Quipu: Calls for Justice
programme.desc: Esperanza and Teodula are calling for justice in rural Peru, part of 300,000 people sterilised without consent more than 18 years ago. The Quipu Project is their phoneline that allows victims across the country to share their shocking testimonies and ensure those responsible are punished.

programme.title: The Apache war against copper mining: 'this is an act of desecration'
programme.desc: Chí’chil Biłdagoteel - otherwise known as Oak Flat, Arizona – is regarded as sacred ancestral land by the Apache people. With the territory at risk of being sold for copper mining to a subsidiary of Rio Tinto, resident Wendsler Nosie has set up a protest movement from his tipi, alongside his daughter and granddaughter. With no support from the courts, Wendsler and the community are anxiously hoping the Biden administration will pause the land transfer. With religious freedom and environmental protection at risk, they await the call with further news.

programme.title: Silent Sam
programme.desc: Sam is a 27-year-old music-teaching, sovereign ring-wearing, chanting Buddhist. He is the lead singer of an up-and-coming punk band - but he’s also mute... at least for most of the time. After two unsuccessful vocal chord operations, Sam spends most of his time in pain and on voice rest. Yet, by communicating silently through writing notes, mouthing words and blowing kisses (one for yes and two for no), he still somehow manages to be the chattiest person in the room.

programme.title: Where the River Runs Red - a mining community caught between the past and a sustainable future
programme.desc: In the isolated west of Tasmania an ominous red river divides the small mining town of Queenstown. A result of copper run-off from a closed mine, it is an ever-present reminder of the town’s history of environmental and industrial disaster. Where the River Runs Red explores a community in an economically crippled area caught between the past and a future that is less reliant on a mining economy.

programme.title: Killing Gävle
programme.desc: In the small city of Gävle, northern Sweden, there is an annual fight between local custodians and mischievous pagans for the spirit of Christmas. Each year since 1966, business owners have paid for a 13-metre (40ft) effigy of a goat to be made of straw and displayed in the central square from the first day of Advent. In 37 of those years, the goat has been burned down or damaged by shadowy outsiders, sometimes within a few hours of going up.

programme.title: Climate carnage: whose job is it to save the planet?
programme.desc: In November last year, the world’s gaze focused on Glasgow at Cop26 as 'a historic, collective achievement' was forged between 200 countries – the Glasgow climate pact. Since then, unprecedented global events have threatened this commitment to limiting climate destruction, and the hopes of 'keeping 1.5 alive' have been dashed. We follow Fiona as she prepares for Cop27 in Egypt, asking presidents, global leaders, activists and scientists if global diplomacy is enough to save humanity from the brink of annihilation.

programme.title: Black Pete | Comedy theatre about life in the Calais refugee camp
programme.desc: Black Pete: Why is the Dutch blackface tradition still going strong? | I don't want any more sadness in my life - comedy theatre about life in the Calais refugee camp

programme.title: How Cape Town stopped the taps running dry | Wrangling Russia: the American cowboys heading east
programme.desc: Day Zero: how Cape Town stopped the taps running dry | Wrangling Russia: the American cowboys heading east

programme.title: The Age of Stupid revisited: what's changed on climate change? | My mission to understand insomnia
programme.desc: The Age of Stupid revisited: what's changed on climate change? | Why can’t I sleep? My mission to understand insomnia

programme.title: The internet warriors
programme.desc: Who are the people that get so angry online? Meet the internet warriors, in their own homes.

programme.title: Burned to the Ground: the Canadian village incinerated by record temperatures
programme.desc: The small village of Lytton in British Columbia hit the global media when it smashed Canada's highest temperature record in June 2021, at 49.6C. Two days later, a wildfire burned the entire village to the ground. In the ashes of their homes, this cohesive but diverse community, which includes a majority of First Nations people, had to confront the realities of climate displacement by being relocated away from their ancestral lands. Through the stories of three residents we find a community searching for answers while relying on a collective spirit to heal

programme.title: Strokestra: The power of music | Dementia Diaries
programme.desc: Hitting the right note: the orchestra helping stroke survivors recover | Dementia Diaries: 'It's like trying to go through a brick wall'

programme.title: La caravana: On the road with the migrant caravan
programme.desc: Thousands of migrants from Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala head north hoping to find work and a better life in the US. The largest Central American caravan in decades keeps growing as thousands more join this journey – but when they reach Mexico, the migrant caravan starts taking different directions.

programme.title: Meet the artists
programme.desc: Adrian Searle's video interviews with some of the scene's leading artists.

programme.title: A sceptic's guide to wellness
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 A sceptic's guide to wellness
programme.desc: Guardian journalist Richard Sprenger journeys into the wellness industry to see what it can offer people with autoimmune conditions.

programme.title: Europeans - Season 1
programme.desc: France: 'Where's the democracy in that?' | Germany: What lies ahead is the past | Ireland: The world needs to get more Irish | Poland: 'Borders bring fear and distrust' | Spain: Europe's one big scam | Sweden: We knew we were the best | UK: I'm British. Island mentality innit

programme.title: The Green Recovery
programme.desc: How to fix Australia's energy-inefficient homes | How to put more electric vehicles on Australia's roads | How Australia can clean up its act on energy | How Australia can close the recycling loop | How Australia can ditch coal (without ditching jobs) | Can I still eat meat if I care about the environment?

programme.title: The Barcelona design studio for people with Down's syndrome and autism | Bright Lights
programme.desc: The Barcelona design studio for people with Down's syndrome and autism | Bright Lights

programme.title: Little Warrior
programme.desc: Johana Gómez, 10-time and reigning amateur featherweight boxing champion, is determined to pull herself and her family out of extreme poverty in Venezuela. Like Gómez, more than 75% of the Venezuelan population lives below the poverty line due to the ongoing economic crisis there. Through a chance online connection with Scottish boxing trainer Gary Young, locked down in Edinburgh, Gómez's hopes of reaching her potential start to take shape - despite the language barrier.

programme.title: The County - what happens after police kill someone you love?
programme.desc: When someone dies after an encounter with law enforcement, he leaves behind parents and children, loss and confusion. What’s to be done when those people sworn to protect you are the same people who pull the trigger?

programme.title: Football helps kids take the right path | Liberi Nantes: a football team made up of refugees
programme.desc: Street children from around the world: 'Football helps kids take the right path' | Liberi Nantes: the first football team in Italy made up of refugees

programme.title: Behind the scenes of Seahorse documentary | If I die on Mars
programme.desc: If all men got pregnant, it'd be taken more seriously': behind the scenes of Seahorse | If I die on Mars: meet the people on a mission to be first on the red planet ... and stay there

programme.title: Dear Bradford: a love letter to a misunderstood city
programme.desc: From Muslim ‘no-go areas’ to Brexit-voting white nationalists, stereotypes continue to be perpetuated about Bradford 21 years after the 'race riots'. Farhaan was born in the city in the 1980s to a family of south Asian Muslim heritage. From a young age he feared being ‘found out’ and lived a dual existence, moving away from Bradford as soon as he could. He spent years travelling the world and teaching English. But, when the coronavirus pandemic hit, Farhaan was reluctantly forced to return to his hometown. Through his beloved grandma, or 'Amma', and the poetry of his late grandfather, Farhaan learned how to love Bradford – and himself.

programme.title: Cinema of Ukraine: artists reflect on modern history, culture and people
programme.desc: Presented in collaboration with the Kyiv-based Docudays UA film festival, these award-winning movies offer insight into the modern history of the country, its culture and its people. In This Rain Will Never Stop, directed by Alina Gorlova, we meet 20-year-old Andriy Suleyman, who escaped Syria with his family and found refuge in Ukraine, his mother’s homeland. Shot in striking black and white, the film is a sophisticated vision of war zones and the scars they leave.

programme.title: No ball games: life and play through the eyes of children across the UK
programme.desc: Celebrating the imagination and resourcefulness of young children across the UK by understanding the outdoor games they invent, inherit and play. The documentary was shot before Covid-19 changed their lives, and shifts from rural Wales to post-industrial Teesside and inner-city London. What challenges will these young people face in the aftermath of brutal funding cuts to youth services? How can their optimistic energy strengthen their resilience in these challenging times?

programme.title: "They're teaching children to hate America": the culture war in US schools
programme.desc: Carmel, Indiana, is an affluent suburb just north of Indianapolis known for low crime rates and some of the country’s best public schools. But early last year, the school board brought in diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives, or DEI, which seek to combat structural racism in the education system. Since then, a battle has erupted between those who welcome the changes, and others who see it as leftwing indoctrination

programme.title: Quipu: Calls for Justice
programme.desc: Esperanza and Teodula are calling for justice in rural Peru, part of 300,000 people sterilised without consent more than 18 years ago. The Quipu Project is their phoneline that allows victims across the country to share their shocking testimonies and ensure those responsible are punished.

programme.title: Heroin to Holyrood? Man behind 'illegal' drug van runs for Scottish parliament
programme.desc: Peter Krykant, who operates a van in Glasgow where people can safely take illegal drugs, is running for Holyrood as part of a campaign calling for the Scottish government to establish legal sites. A former heroin addict, he is pushing for drug reform in Scotland, which has a reported drug deaths rate 15 times higher than the European average. "People are dying out there,' says Krykant, who is able to treat addicts who overdose in his van. Could interventions such as his change Scotland's status as Europe's drug deaths capital?

programme.title: The Battle for Myanmar’s Buddhist spirit
programme.desc: In Myanmar, different groups of Buddhist monks are battling with how to deal with the country’s minority Muslim population. While some advocate peace, others, such as the extremist Ma Ba Tha, are stoking up hatred and violence. The Guardian visited Myanmar to investigate how the monks’ actions are threatening to destabilise the country’s newly established democracy

programme.title: The women on a 'war footing' as the cost of living crisis deepens
programme.desc: People are rationing, it's ridiculous,' says Louise, a co-founder of a community project in Shiremoor, North Tyneside. The Guardian's Maeve Shearlaw and Christopher Cherry went to meet the women who have begun work on transforming a crumbling building into a women-focused support centre in the area that has the highest rate of child poverty in the UK. Louise says it is often women who bear the brunt of the cost of living crisis and every day they are seeing people in need – whether it's asking for period products, help with heating bills or just a warm space to have a cuppa and some company.

programme.title: The Wolf Dividing Norway
programme.desc: With unique access to remote communities in the snow-capped landscape of Norway, this film follows characters on either side of a fierce debate on whether to cull the wolf population. For decades the topic has split political parties, families and communities across the country, with environmentalists world-wide criticising Norway for how it handles its tiny population of critically endangered wolves. .

programme.title: 2020: A Covid Space Odyssey
programme.desc: A short diary of astronaut Jessica Meir during her seven-month mission on the International Space Station (September 2019 - April 2020). Her journey glides from the euphoria of the first days in zero gravity, to the deep pressure of the first all-female space walk in history, and finally to a completely unexpected event: seeing the global pandemic unfold from orbit. The worries slowly start to install in the astronaut's mind, concerned about returning to a 'completely different planet'.

programme.title: Dwarfism and me: 'We're still treated as less than human'
programme.desc: About 90,000 people in America have dwarfism. The writer and podcaster Cara Reedy takes us on a journey to reflect on what it means to be a person with dwarfism – and why America's obsession with little people has left lasting damage.

programme.title: Police Brutality: the families left behind | What does it mean to defund the police?
programme.desc: The families left behind after police killings: 'You never get over losing a child' | What does it mean to defund the police?

programme.title: Can women save sumo? The crossroads facing Japan's national sport
programme.desc: The ancient Japanese sport of sumo is in well-documented crisis. Years of controversy and scandal have hurt the sport's ability to attract new talent. But new energy is brewing in Tokyo's Ryōgoku district, where the sport is slowly adapting to life in the 21st century, and where - despite being banned from the professional ring itself - women are flocking to watch it like never before. Will it be enough to save Japan's national sport in the 21st century?

programme.title: Ghosts of Moria: living in the ashes of Europe's largest migrant camp
programme.desc: As Europe’s most infamous migrant camp burned to the ground on the island of Lesbos in 2020, two Syrian friends evaded police to stay. Living in a post-apocalyptic graveyard, Ayham and Khalil now race against local scrap metal collectors to find what they can, which they are forced to sell at a reduced price. With what little money they make they buy food and cook together, dreaming of Aleppo before the civil war forced them to leave and waiting for an end to their bureaucratic limbo. From their shared tent their friendship endures, despite their impossible circumstances.

programme.title: Meet the people fighting to keep Ireland's abortion ban | Peterloo: A massacre that changed Britain
programme.desc: Meet the people fighting to keep Ireland's abortion ban | A massacre that changed Britain: does Peterloo still resonate today?

programme.title: On the road
programme.desc: Hundreds of women operate as sex workers along the Strada Bonifica, the ironically named ‘road of love’ on the Adriatic coast of Italy. There has been a huge increase in the number of Nigerian women working along the 10-mile stretch of road – some of whom have been trafficked into the country and forced into prostitution. The film moves between the women’s stories, the Italians who live and work there and the local NGO, named On the Road, attempting to support the women

programme.title: Life and death in Texas: abortion frontline of America
programme.desc: New Texan anti-abortion laws are putting women’s lives at risk, according to pro-choice campaigners. But pro-life activists claim they are protecting women from an out-of-control abortion industry. Leah Green visits the state as the battle over women’s bodies intensifies

programme.title: The Breadmaker: Venezuelan activists fighting to feed a community
programme.desc: Natalia Molina and other members of La Minka, a Chavista collective, run a revolutionary bakery in the Venezuelan capital. They have been occupying the shop in Caracas since March 2017 in an attempt to provide their local community with affordable food.

programme.title: 640PM NEWS
programme.desc: Stay informed with the latest breaking news from around the world, every 20 minutes. Keep up-to-date on what’s happening near you, with stories from the world’s most trusted news outlets including ABC, Al Jazeera, Bloomberg, CNBC and Reuters.

programme.title: Nana Akua
programme.desc: Join Nana Akua for a fun and feisty romp through the news. She'll be getting the inside scoop on the stories that matter to you and she'll be taking on the big debates of the day.

programme.title: The Camilla Tominey Show
programme.desc: Highlights from this morning. Join Camilla Tominey for a Sunday morning politics show with personality, live from Westminster.

programme.title: Free Speech Nation
programme.desc: Where journalism and comedy meet - round up of the best and most infuriating stories of Andrew Doyle's week, including a comedy take on the week.

programme.title: Mark Dolan Tonight
programme.desc: Join Mark Dolan, the king of late night weekend chat, for big stories, big guests and big opinions. Expect a lively, intelligent and highly entertaining two hours. You won't want to miss a second.

programme.title: Headliners
programme.desc: The paper review that won't put you to sleep (like the others). Join the all-star comedy cast for an intelligent and insightful look at tomorrow's headlines tonight. Hosts Simon Evans, Andrew Doyle and Leo Kearse.

programme.title: Free Speech Nation Replay
programme.desc: Where journalism and comedy meet - round up of the best and most infuriating stories of Andrew Doyle's week, including a comedy take on the week.

programme.title: UK National Anthem
programme.desc: "God Save the King" is broadcast each morning at 0559 on GB News - Britain's News Channel.

programme.title: Breakfast with Eamonn and Isabel
programme.desc: Join Eamonn Holmes & Isabel Webster to start your day across the United Kingdom. This is your breakfast show. Join the conversation about what is happening in our nation and the world.

programme.title: Britain's Newsroom
programme.desc: Andrew and Bev present every weekday morning. When the news happens, it happens here. But what does it mean for you? GB News brings you the biggest stories and the answers you need from across the UK.

programme.title: Good Afternoon Britain
programme.desc: Tackling the big stories from all angles and perspectives. Weekdays from midday, Tom Harwood and Emily Carver bring you the most compelling stories from across the United Kingdom.

programme.title: Martin Daubney
programme.desc: Join Martin for an up-to-the-minute take on the day's events delivered in his own unique and lively style.

programme.title: Dewbs & Co
programme.desc: Plain-speaking, straight-talking - Michelle delivers her individual take on the day's news.

programme.title: Farage
programme.desc: Nigel Farage doesn't hold back in his GB News prime-time show. Hear his views and give your own in an hour of discussion and debate. Join Nigel as he takes on the big stories other media won't touch.

programme.title: Jacob Rees-Mogg's State Of The Nation
programme.desc: Join Jacob for his unique and unmissable take on the day's news.

programme.title: Patrick Christys Tonight
programme.desc: Join Patrick for two hours of spirited debate and news making interviews. Top guests tackle the issues that matter, with a sharp take on every story.

programme.title: Headliners
programme.desc: The paper review that won't put you to sleep (like the others). Join the all-star comedy cast for an intelligent and insightful look at tomorrow's headlines tonight. Hosts Simon Evans, Andrew Doyle and Leo Kearse.

programme.title: Inheritors
programme.desc: Inheritors is a multi-media product from CGTN that shines a light on China’s rich Intangible Cultural Heritage. Each 30-minute TV edition is hosted by a long-term expatriate in China who has a unique understanding of the country’s culture. He or she will introduce viewers to people who are dedicating their lives to its protection, inheritance, innovation, development and promotion.

programme.title: The World Today
programme.desc: The World Today is the core rolling service of CGTN. keep viewers up-to-date with all the world's top stories as they happen.

programme.title: The Agenda
programme.desc: A weekly talk-show looking beyond the headlines and “accepted wisdom” to find the real story. Hosted by award-winning journalist and presenter Stephen Cole, The Agenda quite simply sets The Agenda . You won’t find the same-old talking heads recycling platitudes; instead thought-provoking guests to debate and explore key issues of today’s world. Using virtual reality graphics to bring subjects to life, Stephen will navigate through subjects ranging from “Prove That Climate Change Exists” to “Who Will Win the Race to Space”. Opposing views will be given opportunity to flourish and develop into a meaningful conversation. The Agenda: No nonsense talk; Challenging perceptions.

programme.title: Africa Live
programme.desc: Africa Live is a news program that focuses on African issues and issues related to this diverse continent. CGTN's Nairobi-based broadcast center produces Africa Live.

programme.title: Talk Africa
programme.desc: Talk Africa is a weekly discussion show that brings the most influential voices in Africa to the world.

programme.title: Sports Scene
programme.desc: Sports Scene brings you closer to all the action from all corners of the world, with highlights from across Europe, North America and China's top sports leagues.

programme.title: Biz Talk
programme.desc: A groundbreaking 30-minute interview show, giving an in-depth look into how top companies around the world conduct business and how policymakers view the fast-changing world economy. It presents 360 degree profiles of industry movers and shakers, tech mavericks and policymakers, and drills down on the stories behind their success, to give you clarity on what’s happening in every facet of business.

programme.title: The World Today
programme.desc: The World Today is the core rolling service of CGTN. keep viewers up-to-date with all the world's top stories as they happen.

programme.title: Travelogue
programme.desc: Travelogue is a 30-minute travel program. Through the journeys of our intrepid hosts, we experience the beauty, culture and mystery of China, discovering how people live in this vast country and showcasing China's transformation to the world.

programme.title: Razor
programme.desc: CGTN's brand new science and technology show, covering cutting edge developments from all over the world. RAZOR will show you the world's most powerful laser and the world's smallest anti-cancer treatment. It will take you from the weird world of quantum computing to the boundaries of the cosmos. An international team of reporters will follow the guidance of Occam's Razor - the principle that the simplest explanation is the best one. RAZOR will show that we are already ""living in the future"!

programme.title: Newcastle

programme.desc: Bones introduces his trademark trickery to people in Paris and Barcelona, performing mind-reading and an attempt to escape a straitjacket while breakdancing.

programme.desc: In this episode Bones is back in his home city, London where he stuns locals with his mind reading, card trickery and disappearing skills.

programme.sub-title: S01 : E03 Around the World in 80 Tricks
programme.desc: Bones is in Seoul, South Korea. He explores the city by night and performs a mixture of magic tricks, including a vanishing trick, coin tricks and card tricks.

programme.desc: In this episode Bones is in South Korea, where he visits Taekwondo group, the K Tigers, a tarot card reader and reveals the secret to the perfect card shuffle.

programme.desc: In this episode Pete take to the streets of India's capital city Delhi. He performs a series of fun and baffling tricks including a levitation attempt.

programme.title: Tim Cridland

programme.title: Ron White

programme.title: Igor Zaripov

programme.title: Scott Flansburg

programme.title: Weeks Of War 7
programme.desc: The events of spring 1944, when on the Eastern Front, the momentum was firmly with Allies as the Second World War moved into its final, violent act.

programme.title: Weeks Of War 8
programme.desc: By January 1945, it seemed the end of the war was in sight, but challenges still loomed on the Eastern Front, in the Pacific and in Western Europe.

programme.title: Rise of The Bomber
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 Bomber: Terror Of WWII
programme.desc: The first bombs were dropped from balloons. During the First World War, Zeppelin airships were used for this, later Gotha planes appeared. Between the wars, more bombers began to be built.

programme.title: War Without Boundaries
programme.sub-title: S01 : E02 Bomber: Terror Of WWII
programme.desc: When the Second World War broke out, bombers were one of the first weapons used in it. Bombings forced the use of gas masks and the construction of shelters, and children were evacuated from bombed-out cities.

programme.title: The Means To Victory
programme.sub-title: S01 : E03 Bomber: Terror Of WWII
programme.desc: Tactics on both sides were developed in both attack and defense. Both the bomber and the defense against it, became more effective through improvements in bombing, navigation, radar development and more.

programme.title: The World At War
programme.sub-title: S01 : E04 Bomber: Terror Of WWII
programme.desc: After the end of the Battle of Britain came the bombing of German cities. In the war in the Pacific, the US and Japan successfully bombed naval and land targets.

programme.title: By Night & By Day
programme.sub-title: S01 : E05 Bomber: Terror Of WWII
programme.desc: The bombing of Tokyo demonstrated the power of the B-29 bomber. The cost of creating this machine exceeds that of the Manhattan Project, which developed the first atomic bomb.

programme.title: Terror of The World
programme.sub-title: S01 : E06 Bomber: Terror Of WWII
programme.desc: In the final months of the Second World War, Adolf Hitler's miracle weapons emerge to turn a lost cause into a victory: the V1 cruise missile and the V2 ballistic missile.

programme.title: Financing Evil
programme.desc: Who financed Hitler and helped him to achieve power?

programme.title: The Nazi Economic Miracle
programme.desc: The first days of Hitler as Chancellor of Germany and the optimistic atmosphere that reigned in the country.

programme.title: The Business Of War
programme.desc: How the extermination of 6 million Jews benefited several industries and businesses in Germany.

programme.title: Aftermath And Injustice
programme.desc: As World War II ended, the hunt for the Nazi criminals began.

programme.title: The Vessels That Saved D-Day
programme.desc: A chronological telling of the dramatic D-Day story, focusing on the vessels that made the landings possible.

programme.title: Weeks Of War 3
programme.desc: From December 1941 to May 1942. Singapore falls, the Wannsee Conference is held in Berlin and a single event in the Pacific transforms the war into a total global conflict.

programme.title: Storming Mussolini's Island
programme.sub-title: S01 : E03 Wwiis Most Daring Raids
programme.desc: Operation Husky, the first invasion of the Italian Campaign. With minimal defence against air and tank assaults, the US Army Rangers know that retreat is not an option.

programme.title: Churchill Strikes Back
programme.sub-title: S01 : E04 Wwiis Most Daring Raids
programme.desc: In December 1941, under cover of a fierce naval bombardment, a taskforce of elite British commandos sail towards the Norwegian town of South Vaagso.

programme.title: The Battle For Berlin
programme.desc: An insight into secret Nazi attempts to turn the tide of war as Berlin crumbled.

programme.title: The U-Boat War
programme.desc: An insight into the Germans' perspective of events as they invaded and battled to the death, featuring expert analysis.

programme.title: The War In Italy
programme.desc: An insight into the Germans' perspective of events as they invaded Italy and battled to the death, featuring expert analysis

programme.title: Secret Weapon Sabotage
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 Wwiis Most Daring Raids
programme.desc: An elite squad of Norwegians destroy a power plant in 1943 that the Nazis may have been using for nuclear weapons research.

programme.title: Cutting Rommel's Lifeline
programme.sub-title: S01 : E02 Wwiis Most Daring Raids
programme.desc: The secret British regiment in 1942 that lead to an attack on a vital Nazi harbour in North Africa. The story follows an SAS force that must escape before the enemies are alerted.

programme.desc: On D-day in 1944 American paratroopers deploy behind German lines. Outnumbered, they attempt to secure territory behind the beaches to ensure the safety of Allied forces as they make their landings.

programme.title: Stealing Hitler's Radar
programme.sub-title: S01 : E06 Wwiis Most Daring Raids
programme.desc: A midnight raid in February 1942 by an elite group of British paratroopers targets a German radar station in an attempt to capture unusual and state-of-the-art military equipment.

programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 Battle Of Britain - The Race For The Radar
programme.desc: Documentary revealing the inside story of the development of Britain's coastal radar network, which did so much to detect and thwart the Luftwaffe's bombing raids on Britain.

programme.title: The Few
programme.desc: Documentay telling the story of the few, the RAF pilots of Battle of Britain

programme.title: Darkest Hour
programme.desc: This episode focuses on events from July to early September 1940, where both sides were finding their feet. The Germans tried initially to bomb British naval shipping with limited success.

programme.title: The Blitz
programme.desc: In September 1940 Hitler targeted London and Britain’s industrial heartlands. Giving the order to Goring to launch what he saw as his final assault on Britain, he sent thousands of German bombers over the capital, catching the outnumbered British off guard.

programme.title: War Against Japan
programme.sub-title: S02 : E10 Soviet Storm: Wwii In The East
programme.desc: In August 1945 the Red Army launched an overwhelming assault against Japanese-occupied Manchuria.

programme.title: Apollo's New Moon
programme.desc: This film shows how collected evidence revolutionized our understanding of the origin of the solar system.

programme.title: When We Were Apollo
programme.desc: Take an intimate and personal look at Apollo through the lives and experiences of its most inspiring figures.

programme.title: Moon Shots
programme.desc: With rare archive footage, this stunning one-hour special brings scientific history to life.

programme.title: Living Planet
programme.sub-title: S03 : E07 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: We have been observing Earth for 40 years now, in the last 20 we have focus with intensity on the planet.

programme.title: Cosmic Collisions
programme.sub-title: S03 : E08 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Stars collide creating monsters of light and energy. Space is a rough place to be.

programme.title: Gravity
programme.sub-title: S03 : E09 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: In space we are merely cheating gravity. Now this fundamental universal force is slowly giving up its secrets.

programme.title: Interface
programme.sub-title: S03 : E10 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: The interface between Earth and space is the Ionosphere, a region of rarified gas and charged particles.

programme.title: The Cryosphere
programme.sub-title: S04 : E01 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: New satellites are finding that climate change is accelerating and they have the data to prove it.

programme.title: Set Course for the Heart of the Sun
programme.sub-title: S04 : E02 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: The NASA's Parker Solar Probe Mission hopes to reveal the source of the solar winds that affect us on Earth.

programme.title: Tickets Please
programme.sub-title: S04 : E03 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Paying customers will soon be launching into space; tourist revenue is projected to be a major stepping stone.

programme.title: Mercury or Bust
programme.sub-title: S04 : E04 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: The ESA-JAXA joint Bepi-Colombo Mission is moments away from launch. This mission will shed light on Mercury.

programme.title: Hyabusa 2
programme.sub-title: S04 : E05 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: The return of asteroid material to Earth will aid scientists in the development in planetary defense systems.

programme.title: Eyes to the Heavens
programme.sub-title: S04 : E06 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Gaia and TESS will be joined by the James Webb Telescope. They will open up a whole new vista into space.

programme.title: Martian Attractions
programme.sub-title: S04 : E07 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: This is the latest in Martian exploration, not just from orbit but also from rovers on the ground.

programme.title: Cubes
programme.sub-title: S04 : E08 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Tiny Satellites are growing in main stream popularity, and are being used for interplanetary missions as well.

programme.title: Proving Einstein
programme.sub-title: S04 : E09 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: It appears that Einstein is once again triumphant as we discover the latest in deep space observations.

programme.title: Where are all the Aliens?
programme.sub-title: S04 : E10 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: We're looking hard, but the numbers aren't stacking up. Is life on other planets really that hard to find?

programme.title: Exoplanets: Thousands of New Worlds
programme.desc: Are we alone? Scientists challenge traditional planetary science to seek and observe worlds called exoplanets.

programme.title: Star Light Star Bright
programme.sub-title: S05 : E01 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Two new space probes can now orbit closer to the Sun than ever before, enabling groundbreaking research.

programme.title: Moon Shine
programme.sub-title: S05 : E02 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Scientists are studying the benefits of a hybrid moon mission, one where humans and robots work in tandem.

programme.title: Rising Tides
programme.sub-title: S05 : E03 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Climate change is causing increasing havoc to our environment. How can science respond to this challenge?

programme.title: Earth's Evil Twin
programme.sub-title: S05 : E04 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Venus may be considered Earth's evil twin. Hostile and unforgiving, Venus is the subject of intense scrutiny.

programme.title: Increasing Orbit
programme.sub-title: S05 : E05 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: The International Space Station is now the only manned station in space, but soon there may be more.

programme.title: Mountains in the Dark
programme.sub-title: S05 : E06 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Asteroids are everywhere in space. We count them, examine why they exist, and track them for Earth's safety.

programme.title: Oceans in the Sky
programme.sub-title: S05 : E07 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: In our search for life beyond Earth, seeking water on other planetary bodies is an important first step.

programme.title: Webb of Life
programme.sub-title: S05 : E08 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: The James Webb Space Telescope will be our key to understanding where we fit in our enormous universe.

programme.title: Peering Into the Abyss
programme.sub-title: S05 : E09 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Time and space converge in black holes. Now we can peer into its abyss to discover its secrets.

programme.title: Next Big Leap
programme.sub-title: S05 : E10 Space: The New Frontier
programme.desc: Earth's new generation of orbiting telescopes promises to expand our universe of knowledge about our origins.

programme.title: The Solar System
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 Life in Outer Space
programme.desc: Scientists are exploring planets and moons that may once have supported life. Saturn's moon, Europa, is one.

programme.title: Apollo's New Moon
programme.desc: This film shows how collected evidence revolutionized our understanding of the origin of the solar system.

programme.title: When We Were Apollo
programme.desc: Take an intimate and personal look at Apollo through the lives and experiences of its most inspiring figures.

programme.desc: Three men sit atop 500 tons of liquid fuel in China's Shenzhou 7 ship, ready to blast 185 miles into space.

programme.sub-title: S01 : E02 Life in Outer Space
programme.desc: The necessary qualities for life may exist on planets outside our Solar System. These are called exoplanets,

programme.title: The Story of Energy
programme.desc: Jim investigates a strange set of laws that link together everything from engines to humans to stars.

programme.title: The Story of Information
programme.desc: Jim learns that information isn't just about human communication; it's woven into the very fabric of reality.

programme.title: The Next Milestone
programme.desc: Asteroids represent one off-Earth option for human colonization. They may be viable, but would be dangerous.

programme.title: The Moon
programme.desc: Space colonization may start with the Moon. Getting material there may be relatively simple. But risks exist.

programme.title: Mars
programme.desc: SpaceX believes that humanity can colonize Mars within our lifetime. Is this goal reasonable? Is it doable?

programme.title: When We Were Apollo
programme.desc: Take an intimate and personal look at Apollo through the lives and experiences of its most inspiring figures.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E03 Over the Islands of Africa, Madagascar
programme.desc: Spirits, Kings, Lemurs – Madagascar treats Ami to a multitude of new impressions and spectacular pictures. Director Christian Schidlowski and his team accompanied her on her trip.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E02 Over the Islands of Africa, Mauritius
programme.desc: Renaud Van Der Meeren is a photographer and paramotor pilot. With his motorised parachute he goes on expeditions to the remotest corners on earth to photograph people and landscapes from the air. Renaud wanted to be a jet pilot, studied music at the Sorbonne, became a ski instructor, model and photographer's assistant before he found happiness in his current vocation. He especially likes to do his job in Mauritius – nowhere else does he find so many motifs as on the "sweetest pearl in the Indian Ocean". This time he's working on a photo book about Mauritius – by land, by water and in the air.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E04 Over the Islands of Africa, Sao Tome and Principe
programme.desc: Along with photographer Rui Camilo, we travel to the West African island nation of Sao Tomé and Príncipe - in search of images that will capture the soul of this small and beautiful country.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 Over the Islands of Africa, Zanzibar
programme.desc: Photographer Matthias Ziegler is an Africa specialist. He has visited nearly every country on the continent on assignments for international agencies. Zanzibar, however, is new territory for him. He's come to the former slave island for a photo book – and this time he's not alone. To see the Tanzanian archipelago from the air, he has enlisted the services of ultralight pilot Richard Meredith-Hardy of England to fly him around in his FIB, or flying inflatable boat. Perfect conditions for an adventurous journey: as a world champion ultralight pilot, Richard and his FIB can take off and land practically anywhere – in theory.

programme.title: Alpine Lakes - Dark Depths and Icy Heights
programme.desc: This is a nature documentary, which leads us into the fascinating world of deep mountain lakes. We conquer ice palaces of unsuspected beauty. In the freezers, in which elves, fairies and mountain trolls once did their mischief, we move, using a special breathing technique and with special cameras in search of nocturnal hunters, whose eyes are equipped with residual light amplifying receptors.

programme.title: Countries People Adventures - Iceland Extreme
programme.desc: In southeastern Iceland, Europe's largest glacier, the gigantic Vatnajökull, covers an area of around 9,000 square kilometers. Beneath it lie the world's most active and dangerous volcanoes. This extreme landscape is as dangerous as it is fascinating: glistening white glacier tongues, lagoons covered with icebergs, bizarre green lava mountains, snow-covered volcanic cones, solidified lava flows and imposing waterfalls overwhelm everyone who gets to see them. In 2008, Icelanders declared the glacier and adjacent areas a national park, the largest in Europe. In this documentary, the team meets people who live, work or do research here: a life with the dangers of fire and ice in the...

programme.title: Europe's Wild River - The Elbe - 1.000 Miles of Wildlife and Nature
programme.desc: The river rises in the Czech Giant Mountains. Here it is called the Labe. After Děčín it flows into Germany and is called Elbe. There are various explanations for the origin of the river name "Elbe". One often mentioned is the Latin name of the river "albia", which means "bright water". This would also explain why the stream is referred to with the feminine article "the Elbe", since the Latin term "albia" is also feminine. Rather poetic than linguistically probable, however, is the explanation that elves (Middle High German: alb) scurrying around the pines in the white river mists could have helped the river to get its name. Geographically, the river can be divided into different...

programme.title: Wildlife Nannies
programme.sub-title: S02 : E02 Wildlife Nannies: Spa Day
programme.desc: A spa day of back scrubbing, massage and more for the manatees of Homosassa Springs Wildlife State Park.

programme.title: Wildlife Nannies
programme.sub-title: S02 : E03 Wildlife Nannies: Abandoned Fawn
programme.desc: An abandoned fawn is found in woods.and is brought to Fawn Wildlife Rescue Station with a broken leg.

programme.title: Wildlife Nannies
programme.sub-title: S02 : E04 Wildlife Nannies: Orphaned Seals
programme.desc: Along the rugged coast of Aquarium, Vancouver there are orphaned and injured seals that need help.

programme.title: Wildlife Nannies
programme.sub-title: S02 : E05 Wildlife Nannies: Bat Nanny
programme.desc: Will a bat nanny help a bat fledgling learn how to fly and be released back into the night skies?

programme.title: Zoo Babies
programme.sub-title: S01 : E08 Zoo Babies - Cute and curious, Ep. 8
programme.desc: We find out about the sweetest and most poignant animal baby stories. Whether on land, under water or in the sky - all of the babies in this series will conquer the hearts of all those watching. We accompany the adventures of the animal babies - lovingly cared for and brought up by their keepers. In the most gripping and informative way, both young and old will discover everything there is to know about Hamburg Zoo's toddlers.

programme.title: Treasure of Lima - Buried Exhibition
programme.desc: This is a story about a remote island in the pacific.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E05 Over the Islands of Africa, Cape Verde
programme.desc: Cape Verde – the islands of Saudade, of longing. For Stéphane and Richard it was a journey full of adventure, unforgettable encounters and magnificent photographs. Director Christian Schidlowski and his team accompanied them on their trip.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E03 Over the Islands of Africa, Madagascar
programme.desc: Spirits, Kings, Lemurs – Madagascar treats Ami to a multitude of new impressions and spectacular pictures. Director Christian Schidlowski and his team accompanied her on her trip.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E02 Over the Islands of Africa, Mauritius
programme.desc: Renaud Van Der Meeren is a photographer and paramotor pilot. With his motorised parachute he goes on expeditions to the remotest corners on earth to photograph people and landscapes from the air. Renaud wanted to be a jet pilot, studied music at the Sorbonne, became a ski instructor, model and photographer's assistant before he found happiness in his current vocation. He especially likes to do his job in Mauritius – nowhere else does he find so many motifs as on the "sweetest pearl in the Indian Ocean". This time he's working on a photo book about Mauritius – by land, by water and in the air.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E04 Over the Islands of Africa, Sao Tome and Principe
programme.desc: Along with photographer Rui Camilo, we travel to the West African island nation of Sao Tomé and Príncipe - in search of images that will capture the soul of this small and beautiful country.

programme.title: Over the Islands of Africa
programme.sub-title: S01 : E01 Over the Islands of Africa, Zanzibar
programme.desc: Photographer Matthias Ziegler is an Africa specialist. He has visited nearly every country on the continent on assignments for international agencies. Zanzibar, however, is new territory for him. He's come to the former slave island for a photo book – and this time he's not alone. To see the Tanzanian archipelago from the air, he has enlisted the services of ultralight pilot Richard Meredith-Hardy of England to fly him around in his FIB, or flying inflatable boat. Perfect conditions for an adventurous journey: as a world champion ultralight pilot, Richard and his FIB can take off and land practically anywhere – in theory.

programme.title: Portugal's Nature Parks
programme.desc: The Parque Nacional Peneda-Gerês is the only national park in Portugal. An area of almost 700 square kilometers, located in the extreme north of Portugal. Barren and rocky ridges in the plateaus, contrast with large forests and lush ground vegetation in deep valleys, crossed by lakes and rivers. The park is known for its oak forests, which are predominantly pedunculate and Pyrenean oaks. Among the typical animals of the park are the small Garrano ponies, a very old breed of horse and the only one in Europe that still lives in the wild.

programme.title: Portugal's Nature Parks
programme.desc: The "Parque Natural da Ria Formosa" is one of the largest lagoon conservation areas in Europe. Bordered by five natural islands. A mosaic of sandbanks, brackish and freshwater lagoons and salt marshes. In 2010, the "Ria Formosa" was chosen as one of the seven natural wonders of Portugal. It is a unique ecosystem: in the winter months, more than 20,000 birds gather here. In addition, the nature park has one of the largest seahorse populations internationally. More than half of all fish species in the Atlantic are said to spawn in the lagoon.

programme.title: Portugal's Nature Parks
programme.desc: The highest mountain range in Portugal is the Serra da Estrela. The episode embarks on a voyage of discovery to adventurous rock formations and villages steeped in tradition. The nature park is the largest protected area on the Iberian peninsula. In the mountain range we accompany the young scientist Ana Matos, who wants to breathe new life into old traditions, and cheese maker Maria Natália Lopes. She watches over more than 350 sheeps.

programme.title: Portugal's Nature Parks
programme.sub-title: S01 : E03 South West Portugal: Alentejano and Costa Vicentina
programme.desc: In the southwest of Portugal lies the little known Parque Natural do Sudoeste Alentejano e Costa Vicentina. It encompasses a narrow coastal strip that runs along the coast to the south of Portugal. Sparsely populated, this coastal region, which was placed under protection in 1988, is considered one of the last intact ecosystems in Europe. The steep cliffs, the almost constant wind and high waves have ensured that mass tourism has not gained a foothold here. There are still near-natural forests and a diverse bird life.

programme.title: The Canary Islands - In the Shadows of the Volcanoes
programme.desc: The Canary Islands were born in the depths of the ocean. Forged by fire and sculpted by winds and waves, this volcanic land offers landscapes of colossal force and almost unreal beauty.

programme.title: Myths of the Congo - Apes and Aliens
programme.desc: The Congo, mighty and deep like no other river - yet still a retreat and a habitat for several of our world's strangest animals. Our closest relatives live deep inside the dense jungles: three of the four giant ape species have made the Congo basin their home. Rich in extraordinary footage, the second episode of "Myths of the Congo" also presents exciting insights into one of the most mysterious and dangerous regions on earth.

programme.title: Myths of the Congo - Deep and Dangerous
programme.desc: The river that swallows all rivers - this is what the natives call it. In reality, the Congo, when considering its water masses, is the second largest and the deepest river in the world. At its source in the north of Zambia, it starts out as a mere trickle, but on its journey westwards it grows and grows, becoming ever mightier and with it, the animals, too: the shoebill stork hides in the dense papyrus. Metre-long pythons hunt for their prey in trees and huge hippos fight for power and respect in the water. To survive in the Congo, animals have to adapt to extreme conditions. Here, evolution has spawned unique creatures: fish with lungs, wings and those that go hunting on land. The Congo...

programme.title: Portugal's Nature Parks
programme.desc: Madeira - Portugal's autonomous island in the Atlantic Ocean, is closer to the African coast than to the mother country Portugal, from which it is separated by about 900 kilometers. The island's name comes from Portuguese sailors who claimed the uninhabited isle for themselves in 1419. Madeira means wood and that was available in abundance. Almost the entire surface was covered by dense forest. Since 1982, two-thirds of the landscape has been protected.

programme.title: Wild Bavaria
programme.desc: The moon disappears behind the horizon and the stage is set for a new day in the Alps of Berchtesgaden.

programme.title: Wild Bavaria
programme.sub-title: S01 : E02 Wild Bavaria - In The Shadow of the Watzmann.
programme.desc: Mighty and mysterious, King Watzmann sits above Germany's only alpine national park.

programme.title: Skate Dreams
programme.desc: This collection of films explores the transformative power of skateboarding. From India, to Greece, to Morocco, these films remind us that with courage and determination, anything is possible.

programme.title: Resilience
programme.desc: Resilience is an action-sport documentary film about big-mountain riding, human resilience and what it means to truly be connected. Up next: Days Off.

programme.title: An Hour On Our Planet
programme.desc: “An Hour on Our Planet,” a Rolex Perpetual Planet film, explores global initiatives from coral reefs to glaciers, showcasing NGOs like One Ocean Foundation, Mission Blue, and inspiring individuals.

programme.title: Truluck
programme.desc: After a surprise encounter with a humpback whale ignites Steve Truluck’s hidden passion for marine life, he decided to trade his mundane 9-5 for his unexpected purpose - becoming one of the UK’s leading whale-watching guides. Up next: Choose Magic.

programme.title: Skid Row Marathon
programme.desc: Craig Mitchell, a Los Angeles Superior Court Judge, changes lives by leading the long-distance runner's club out of the Midnight Mission on Skid Row. Up next: meet the Dance Crews of Dzaleka Refugee camp in Dance for Change.

programme.title: Restoring Our Reefs
programme.desc: This collection of films dives into the various ocean restoration projects ongoing across the world, from the offshore wind farms of Taiwan, to the local guardians of Colombian coastal areas, and Australia's Great Barrier Reef.

programme.title: Stories from the Summits
programme.desc: This collection of stories about climbing goes deep into various US-based communities to reveal the positive impacts of getting outdoors and in touch with the earth.

programme.title: Tidal
programme.desc: Tidal follows Lisa Beasley’s journey after a horrific BASE jumping accident encourages her to return to the ocean, leading her to discover and protect the beauty of Cape Town's tidal pools and the life within them.

programme.title: The Land of the Bear
programme.desc: Human interference has threatened the survival of wild bears all over the world. Follow the stories of the remaining wild bears and meet those working to promote coexistence between our species.

programme.desc: An Artist, a Musician and a Dreamer, all of them British, have moved to Rio's notorious favela communities where they build their lives in perilously-shifting political sands.

programme.title: Local Thirty
programme.desc: A documentary film following Andrea Bemis and her family as they visit 5 producers from the Oregon coast to the Oregon ranching community during a month-long commitment to a diet of foods grown or harvested within 200 miles of their Parkdale, Oregon.

programme.title: Let Us Be Heroes
programme.desc: How much difference can one person make? Let Us Be Heroes explores the impact of our food and lifestyle choices on our health, our planet and our values by sharing inspiring stories from athletes, food, and fashion entrepreneurs.

programme.title: Barbie's Pink World
programme.desc: A documentary for children about the incredible story of Barbie, from the toy’s origins to the 2023 first live action film, directed by award-winning Director Greta Gerwig. Featuring Vox pops from the film actors such as Margot Robbie, Ryan Gosling, and America Ferrera. The story of how Barbie has become a cherished part of so many little girl’s childhood memories.

programme.title: Taylor Swift: Superstar
programme.desc: Taylor Swift completed her transition from country star to pop superstar. With exclusive interviews and footage, discover the remarkable story of the most powerful woman in Pop.

programme.title: Beyonce: Queen B

programme.title: The Dolly Parton Story: From Rags to Rhinestones
programme.desc: Dolly Parton is one of the most iconic singer-songwriters of all time. From her humble beginnings - one of 12 children living in a shack in Tennessee - Dolly has not only conquered the Country music scene, but made her mark on the entertainment industry.

programme.title: The Taylor Swift Story: Dare To Dream
programme.desc: The incredible journey of Taylor Swift all began with a girl, a guitar and a dream. Taylor Swift is a ten time Grammy winner, and the youngest recipient in history of the music industry’s highest honour, follow the story of an artist who turned a childhood dream into an empire.

programme.title: Depp VS Heard: The Verdict
programme.desc: Heard says Depp abused her. Depp says Heard abused him. So what’s the truth? After short deliberations the verdict was in... This is... Depp vs Heard: The Verdict.

programme.title: Elvis & Priscilla: Conditional Love
programme.desc: Elvis and Priscilla are one of the most famous celebrity couples of all time. But the story that lies beneath the glamorous facade is more toxic than what first meets the eye.

programme.title: Crypto Farmers - Censored
programme.desc: Can you make money from manure? Farms are struggling to get by in this modern world. Farmers are forced to diversify their income steams in order to survive. With a remarkable new invention from a young entrepreneur farmers in rural Wales are now heating up piles of cow manure to power crypto mining rigs.

programme.title: Ninety-five Senses
programme.desc: Narrated by Tim Blake Nelson, this is an ode to the body's five senses delivered by a man with little time left to enjoy them. An Oscar nominated DOCUMENTARY+ Original. Directed by Jared and Jerusha Hess.

programme.title: The Last 24 Hours: Prince
programme.desc: The world mourned the loss of one of it’s most innovative performers in April 2016. While Prince’s official autopsy confirmed that the singer died from an overdose of the painkiller fentanyl, investigators have still been looking to clear up some additional mysteries surrounding the case. We take a look into the last 24 hours of his death and look for the real answers as to what happened.

programme.title: The Last 24 Hours: Michael Jackson
programme.desc: The ultimate king of pop Michael Jackson spent his last hours battling insomnia and pleading with his personal physician to give him a powerful anesthetic to combat his chronic sleeplessness according to a search-warrant affidavit. We explore the truth behind this and discover the real facts, with exclusive footage and testimonials.

programme.title: The Last 24 Hours: John Lennon
programme.desc: On the morning of December 8, 1980 John Lennon was happy in New York and looking forward to the future. Having just turned 40 he had finally recovered from the years as a Beatle. But by the end of that day John would be dead and the world would be in mourning. Here are the final 24 hours of the ex-Beatle’s life before he was so senselessly murdered by Mark David Chapman."

programme.title: The Last 24 Hours: Amy Winehouse
programme.desc: After a very public battle with addiction the world was saddened to hear the shocking news that Amy Winehouse was found dead in her bedroom at the young age of 27. We investigate what really happened during the final 24 hours of the singer’s life, with exclusive interviews and testimonials.

programme.title: The Last 24 Hours: Elvis Presley
programme.desc: The true story of Elvis Presley's last 24 hours is told by the men who knew him best, his Memphis Mafia.

programme.title: The Last 24 Hours: Jimi Hendrix
programme.desc: This documentary offers an in-depth look at Jimi Hendrix's last 24 hours and attempts to clear the air surrounding his tragic passing by including appearances and testimonials from some of the people that knew him best.

programme.title: The Diana Conspiracy: What Happened In Paris?
programme.desc: Join us as we uncover the conspiracy theories that could point to an alternative and much more sinister explanation for the sudden and tragic death of Princess Diana.
